review.title: Realization of Ontology Web Search Engine
review.abstract: This paper describes the realization of the Ontology Web Search Engine. The Ontology Web Search Engine is realizable as independent project and as a part of other projects. The main purpose of this paper is to present the Ontology Web Search Engine realization details as the part of the Semantic Web Expert System and to present the results of the Ontology Web Search Engine functioning. It is expected that the Semantic Web Expert System will be able to process ontologies from the Web, generate rules from these ontologies and develop its knowledge base.

metadata.title: REALIZATION OF ONTOLOGY WEB SEARCH ENGINE

sections.heading: II. ONTOLOGY WEB SEARCH ENGINE STRUCTURE
sections.text: The task of ontology search requires its decision a long time ago. As is well known, the need to make suggestions, and the solution of ontology search has been found soon. One of these suggestions identifies the steps of ontology search and also defines input as a set of search terms and defines the output as a list of ontologies [7]. This was the most used schema of semantic search, which has been realized many times in the form of the semantic web search engines. SWOOGLE is one of the semantic web search engines for indexing and restoring the semantic web documents, including RDF (Resource Description Framework) and OWL [8]. SWOOGLE is realized as a web page, and it is available at http: / swoogle.umbc.edudududududu.

sections.heading: III. ONTOLOGY WEB SEARCH ENGINE REALIZATION AND TESTING
sections.text: It is indeed the case that most of us are able to go in search of a solution worthy of the name, "he said." But it is not the case that we go in search of a solution, "he said." sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper demonstrates the realization and test results of the Ontology Web Search Engine as part of the Semantic Web Expert System. It is obvious that the realization of the Ontology Web Search Engine as a standalone and professional system requires the improvement of all parts of the Ontology Web Search Engine. For example, it is possible that the crawler and the indexer must work in parallel when we talk about professional ontology Web Search Engine. Found ontology URLs must be stored in the database, but not in the text file. It is possible that the crawler must be implemented in programming language C + + in order to work faster. In turn, there is the need for indexing of all ontologies, regardless of the format of the ontologies. In this context, it is necessary to provide another framework for ontology processing in addition to Apache Jena.As for the general conclusions, ontologies cannot completely supplant the regular web pages.

referenceMentions.context: The development of the Web has provided us with more information than we can comprehend or manage effectively [1].
Finally, retrieved results are single web pages and hence it is necessary manually extract the partial information and put it together [3].
The task of rule generation from OWL ontologies had already been solved [6].
One of such proposals identified the steps of the ontology search and also defined the input as a set of keywords and defined the output as a list of ontologies [7].
SWOOGLE was one of the Semantic Web search engines for indexing and retrieving the Semantic Web documents including RDF (Resource Description Framework) and OWL [8].
The typical structure of a web search engine comprises four essential modules [10]:
Crawlers are computer programs that browse the Web [10].
The indexer takes all the words from each document in the page repository and records the URL, where each word occurred [10].
The web query engine receives the search requests from users [10].
The page repository stores the Web content that was retrieved during the crawling process [10].
